text: in this video we're going to set up
neovim to be the almost perfect editor
for working with node.js by the end of
this guide you'll have code completion
and auto suggestions linting with static
analysis Auto formatting on Save and
Powerful debugging capabilities I've
also added in a custom LSP function at
the end we'll be supporting both
JavaScript and typescript with this
configuration so you can use whichever
language you prefer to get started
you're going to need to install the
latest version of neovim on your system
as of the time of recording that is
0.9.1 go ahead and install it as per
your operating system I'm using Arch by
the way so I'll install it using Pac-Man
with neovim installed the next thing
you're going to want is to install a
nerd font this will provide some really
nice icons inside of neovim personally I
use the jetbrains mono nerd font as it's
one of my favorites make sure to install
it as per your operating system
with the font installed you'll also need
to make sure your terminal application
is configured to use it I'm using
alacrity so I just need to add the entry
to my alacrity.yamo the final dependency
you'll need to install is git which will
allow us to download our base
configuration make sure to also install
this as per your operating system with
our requirements installed we can now
begin setting up our configuration to
assist with this we're going to install
a base configuration to give us a number
of features out of the box there are a
few decent base configurations out there

first want to backup your configuration
folder using the following command
afterwards make sure to go ahead and

in the description
once it's finished go ahead and open up

to choose Capuchin because well it's the
best with that done our base
configuration is set up and we're ready

feature we're going to add is code
suggestions and auto completion with
some additional light static analysis
we're going to achieve this by

in our case we're going to install the

for both JavaScript and typescript
to add this we're first going to need to

the tree view opened head down to the
lower custom directory and open up the
chadrc.lure file this file is used for
storing our general NV chat
configuration inside of this file you
can see that we're creating a lure table
called M and setting the ui's theme
value to be Capuchin this was done when
we selected our theme earlier underneath
the UI go ahead and add in the following

allows us to add new plugins or

this file name as custom.plugins which
in Lua means the custom slash plugins
file which we need to create to do so
head back over to the tree View and
press the a key this will generate a

we can use to create our new file with
go ahead and give this the name of

however the first thing we need to do is
make sure it's installed on our system
you can install the typescript language
server using your operating systems

the benefit to using Mason is it keeps

very good thing to use Mason first add

table next add in a table for both the

with our plugins table set up we now

installs anything that's in our ensure

with the typescript server installed the
next package we're going to override is

out of the box to do so add in the
following entry to our custom plugins
table inside of this entry go ahead and

which we'll use to specify some

first import the default nvchat

file let's go back into our tree View
Press the a key and add in a new

inside of this file we're going to store

only the types server at this stage
first import the default and V chat

we then want to pull out the on attach

to set up the typescript language server
add the following line which calls the

add in the on attach and capabilities
values that we pulled out of the default
MV chat config next you'll want to set
the init
options.preferences.disable suggestions
value to be true when testing this
config I found that the LSP server would
often provide suggestions that weren't
able to be acted on which just caused
needless clutter therefore this option
disables that making the whole
experience cleaner now let's go ahead
and test this if I jump on over to a

suggestions when I type in the module

suggestions using Ctrl n or Ctrl P which
stands for next or previous as well as
typescript the code completion also
works for JavaScript here you can see I
have order suggestions for my require
statement which shows me a list of
node.js packages I can import and with
that our LSP is working as expected
the next feature we're going to add is
encode static analysis or linting to our
projects there are a number of different
linters for node.js out there whilst
doing my research for the video I really
wanted to use a tool called biome
however I discovered there was a real
lack of neovim support that being said
this project is still pretty appealing
to me for a few reasons the first is
that it's an opinionated linter
formatter and analyzer all in one and
the second is that it's written in Rust
therefore I'm going to attempt to build
a custom neovin plugin to use this in
the future especially as it provides its
own LSP server if you're interested in
me doing a video on this then please let
me know in the comments down below so as
I wasn't going to use biome for this
project what was I going to use instead
well I decided to use es lint as it's
pretty ubiquitous and used across a lot
of JavaScript and typescript projects
and so the first thing to do was to get
eslint installed now there were some
carriers with this as eslint can be
installed either in a project or on a

using the eslint LSP package which
provides support for both so let's go
ahead and add that to our ensured
installed options and run Mason install
all next we needed to decide how to
actually load this into neovim
historically on this series we would use
null LS to do this however it has since
been archived so we needed another
option I wanted to take inspiration from
what the rest of the neovim community
were using however like some British
wartime propaganda they had decided to
keep calm and carry on therefore I
decided to follow the advice of the
creator of nvchad and use some different
solutions this solution was nvim lint
which provides bindings for a number of
different lenses whilst it doesn't
support biome out of the box it does
support eslint so we're going to use it
to do so let's add an entry to our
plugins table in our custom plugins.lure
inside of this entry we're also going to
add a config function and import a
custom configuration this will be our
lint dot lure file that we're going to
go ahead and create now then let's open
up this new file inside we add in the
following lines to set up eslint for
both the JavaScript and typescript file
types if you want you can check out the
documentation for other supported
linters and add them to different file
types if you like next because this
linter is not LSP based we need to add
in a method so that it lints whenever we
save our file this for me actually is a
bit of a drawback and I much prefer the

on that in a minute go ahead and add in
the following lines to set up a new auto
command for whenever we save this
command will run after we save and we'll

with that done we can go ahead and test
it out to start with eslint you'll first
need a DOT eslint RC file inside of your
project directory this file allows you
to configure your linter for whatever
rules you wanted to run you can generate
an eslint file by using the npm init at
eslint config command and filling out
your configuration as prompted by the
tool next I have some JavaScript code
here to show the linter working in my
case my code should expect to have
semicolons and to use use double quotes
instead of single ones you'll notice
that I have no errors at this stage
however when I go to save my file the
errors will appear this differs from an
LSP approach such as with a null LS
which will show the errors as they
happen for me I prefer the null LS
Behavior over this so I'm going to show
you how to actually set up null LS later
on however remember that null LS has
been archived and neovim lint will last
much much longer so the choice is yours
before I show you how to set up null LS
for linting let's look at our next
feature
the next feature we're going to add is

like with linting I originally wanted to
do this with biome however because of
the same reasons I decided to go with
prettier instead which is another
opinionated yet popular code formatter
we can install this with Mason by adding
prettier to the ensure installed block
then we just need to run the Mason
install all command if you don't see

the command restart neovim and try again
with prettier installed the next thing
we need to do is configure it to work
with neovim again this would have

therefore I needed another option so for

nvchad setting this up is pretty similar

adding an entry to the plugins table
this entry also loads in a custom

options block rather than the config
block next is to go ahead and create
this custom format matter configuration
to do so create a new file in the
configs directory called formatter.lure
open this file up and create and return
an empty lure table inside of this table
will contain another table for our file
types where we will specify the
different formatters we want to use for
each file type respectively inside We'll
add the prettier formatter for both
JavaScript and typescript whilst also
adding a trailing white space remover
for any file type next we need to enable
auto formatting whenever we save this is
different to how we would do it with

to our buffer which we'll call the

some poorly formatted JavaScript at

little bit janky when compared to null
or less additionally when I tried to

didn't feel like a perfect solution but
it did get the job done so I do
recommend giving this a go but you may
feel like me and want to still use
nonetheless fortunately I can give you a
quick speed run on how to do that
first things first you'll want to delete

with that being said whilst null LS does

I've shown you how to both add
formatting and linting Via null LS let's
move on to our penultimate feature the
last big feature we're going to add is
debugging for our node.js code from
within neovim to do that we're going to
use a plugin called mvmdap which stands
for the debug adapter protocol and
allows for text editors to communicate
with debuggers in my research there were
a number of different debuggers for
node.js with the most popular one being
node 2. which is unfortunately archived
however this has been replaced with the
official vs code debugger which also
happens to work with neovim to set this
up we need to install this debugger
using Mason to do that go ahead and add
the following entry to the insure
installed block next we can add an entry
to our plugins table for the MVM dap
plugin and inside another config
function which Imports yet again another
custom configuration file this is the
last one and I promise next go ahead and
create the dap.lure file in the custom
configuration directory and open it up
inside of this file we need to define a
Dap adapter for pwa node which will
connect to the JS debug adapter server
afterwards we can specify a
configuration for both JavaScript and
typescript which will use the pwa node
type and launch it against the current
file we're working in this is a little
bit of boilerplate at this stage but
just bear with me with that we have a
working debugger but we want to specify
some UI to go with it for that we're
going to use the nvimdap UI package to
do so we just need to add the entry into
our custom plugins table and make sure
to add a dependency to nvimdap this
means whenever this plugin is loaded and
the DAP will be loaded as well next
create a config function with the
following lines of code in it this code
adds three different event listeners to
mvimdat which hooks up to these
callbacks when events happen this means
the UI will automatically open when the
debugger is run and automatically close
when the debugger is exited with that
the debugger is set up however I like to
add some custom key mappings in order to
make debugging just a little bit easier
to do so first create a mappings.lure
file in the custom directory inside
create a new lure table called M and
return it next inside of this table
specify an entry for dap this is where
we're going to store all of our dap
based mappings go ahead and set the
plugin value to true this means the
mappings will only be applied when we
explicitly load them next we'll go ahead
and set a table for the N key which
means normal mode and add in our first
mapping for the leader key or space key
D and B this mapping will toggle a
breakpoint at the current line our
cursor is on we'll also want to add a
new mapping to run our debugger let's go
ahead and set this to leader or space d
and r this will call the DAP continue
command which will both start the
debugger or resume it if it's already
running but paused with our mappings
file set up we just need to go ahead and
load them for first head back on over to
the plugins.lure file inside add the
following line to the nvimdap
configuration function this will load
the DAP mappings whenever the nvimdap
plugin is loaded the final thing we need
to do is jump on over to the chatrc.lure
file and import our mappings assigning
them to the mappings key of the M table
with that we can go ahead and test our
debugger heading on over to a Fibonacci
function I made earlier we can set a
breakpoint on our current line by using
the space D and B mappings that we
configured earlier you can see that a
breakpoint is active by the letter B
next to the line number with our
breakpoint set we can go ahead and run
our debugger by using the space d and r
key mapping once the debugger is run a
number of windows will open up this is
the MVM dap UI and gives us a bunch of
information about our debugging session
as well as a number of buttons we can
use to control the debugger and with
that we have working debug capabilities
from within near them now typically this
is where I would finish up these videos
in this series but I wanted to have one

let's jump on over to the final feature
we're going to add
for this final feature we're going to

this is to get us working a little bit

with biome to add this new feature head

above the TS server configuration let's
create a new function called organize
Imports inside of this function create a
lure table called params we'll send the
contents of this table to our LSP server
the first parameter we want to send is
the LSP command which is the underscore
typescript.organize Imports command and
the second is our arguments field which
will contain the current Buffer's file
path with our parameters defined we can
go ahead and call the execute command of
the vim.lsp.buff API whilst also passing
in our parameters this allows us to send
the command to our LSP server next we
want to specify a custom Vim command so
that we can call this on demand to do
that add in a commands block to the
setup function of the TS server and add
in a new command of organize Imports
inside of this table specify the
organize Imports function and give it a
nice description now if we jump on over
to some typescript code we can invoke
this command using the colon key
followed by the command name which is
organize Imports the LSP server will
then organize our Imports for us as well
as removing any that we're not using
pretty neat but the real power here is
that you just managed to create your own
LSP binding all by yourself and that
